name: NPR
text:
A broken cable at Puerto Rico's Arecibo Observatory tore a gaping 100-foot hole in one of the largest radio telescopes in the world, taking it offline until repairs can be made.
https://t.co/a13WPnBLQJ

name: NPR
text:
A new report says since George Floyd died:

• 38 Confederate monuments were taken down & 5 more relocated
• 16 schools, parks & other locations were renamed
• 1 state retired its flag
• 1 town removed the Confederate flag from its police badge https://t.co/NYfeN53skw

name: NPR
text: RT @wosunews: NEW: Secretary of State Frank LaRose is instructing county boards of elections that only one secure ballot drop box will be allowed for each county. https://t.co/vlHngTG0vn

name: NPR
text: President Trump spent much of his daily briefing Wednesday railing against additional funding to support the Post Office and mail-in voting — repeating the unsubstantiated claim that voting by mail is ripe for fraud. https://t.co/0JpDEaj3aW

name: NPR
text: Kamala Harris is not only the first woman of color to appear on a major U.S. presidential ticket. She's the first person of South Asian descent, too — which many are celebrating in India, where her mother was from. https://t.co/Pk4glQFdmi

name: NPR
text: Enormous, 33-foot-long "terror crocodiles" with huge teeth once roamed North America and preyed on big dinosaurs. Researchers say the species disproves the idea that alligators and crocodiles are living fossils, showing how far they've evolved.  https://t.co/egJDOXu7YS

name: NPR
text:
Three longtime members of the Minneapolis music scene are trying to start a new venue aimed at fostering art from marginalized communities.

But substantial start-up costs and the Covid-19 crisis are among the mounting challenges. https://t.co/ehZsRJyw6a

name: NPR
text:
President Trump’s move to limit high-skilled immigration to the U.S. may not save jobs for Americans — it might actually cost jobs.

Even with restrictions, businesses still have several other options to get the work done. https://t.co/cq0qioK49f

name: NPR
text:
A laid-off toy maker putting on puppet shows in his living room window for passersby. Two siblings helping local businesses provide low-cost meals to immigrant families in need. 

Here are six profiles of volunteers making a difference during the pandemic. https://t.co/9S910eOIRM

name: NPR
text: The HBO miniseries "Watchmen" takes place within a big, weird world that keeps getting bigger and weirder, even as it seeks to comment on some very contemporary, real-world issues.  https://t.co/u1iTrK83HS

name: NPR
text:
A new documentary follows Texas Boys State, a week-long summer experiment in which teens form their own representative democracy.  

The mock election highlights flaws of the real-life system.
https://t.co/aPiDJQYv8m

name: NPR
text:
The Colorado music community united for “Home But Not Alone," an online concert to help those struggling with mental health during the coronavirus pandemic.
https://t.co/ulWqF6Vm8x

name: NPR
text:
A week ago, the Big Ten released its fall football schedule. Now, that season is on hold — giving fans a case of whiplash.

"They kind of build you up and then pull the rug out from under you," an Ohio State fan said. 
https://t.co/civ0WMkzsQ

name: NPR
text: A $765 million government loan for Kodak was blocked after the SEC launched an insider trading investigation. A huge amount of the company's shares were sold the day before the announcement. Some say the deal looked financially shaky even before the probe. https://t.co/jq5A6k3YoM

name: NPR
text: The band @Indigo_Girls has shaped a generation of singer-songwriters. Amy Ray and Emily Saliers talk about their lifelong bond and the poetic flair of Kae Tempest. https://t.co/QHy2fHpz1g

name: NPR
text: Hundreds of colleges across the country are getting ready to welcome students back this fall -- after they waive their right to sue if they get sick or die after catching the new coronavirus on campus. @wgbhnews https://t.co/PzeUbY39mY

name: NPR
text: If Joe Biden wins the election, his Justice Department will have to decide whether to investigate and prosecute President Trump. Biden so far has been cautious with the question, saying he wouldn't interfere, but that such a move may be bad for democracy. https://t.co/Ff5JgqSbeh

name: NPR
text: U.S. military academies are hopeful that discipline, frequent testing, and staggered and quarantined arrivals will keep coronavirus outbreaks to a minimum. But the students had doubts that  the methods would work at less controlled civilian campuses. https://t.co/0pTTbXBxSH

name: NPR
text: First-time claims for state unemployment benefits dropped below 1 million last week for the first time in five months. Claims under a special pandemic program for gig workers and others who are typically not eligible for unemployment also fell. https://t.co/sGWFUYs2XD
